author: Seattle Times staff
title: Who they were: The 3 firefighters killed near Twisp
text:
Officials have identified the U.S. Forest Service firefighters killed near Twisp, Okanogan County, on Wednesday as Richard Wheeler, 31; Andrew Zajac, 26; and Tom Zbyszewski, a 20-year-old student at Whitman College in Walla Walla.
A fourth firefighter, 25-year-old Richard Lyon, was in critical condition at Harborview Medical Center with burns over 60 percent of his body.
The three were killed and Lyon was injured Wednesday while they were fighting a fast-moving fire outside of Twisp.
Details of the deaths were not immediately available, but officials have said that the firefighters had been involved in a vehicle accident and that the crew was apparently overtaken by the fire they had been fighting.
Most Read Stories Wind-whipped wildfire kills 3 firefighters, injures 4 near Twisp No bodies found in wreckage of Bremerton motel Cascadia fault chatters and pops with little quakes When fire chief called for help, and no one was left State cracks down on fraudulent immigration aid Four other firefighters, including Lyon, were injured in the Twisp fire, including another Forest Service firefighter, two firefighters from the state Department of Natural Resources and one DNR contractor.
Three of the four firefighters were released from local hospitals Thursday, said Carrie McCausland, a DNR spokeswoman. The firefighters, whose injuries were not described, included two of the DNR employees and the contractor. She would not say where they were treated.
 Related video: Aerial view of wildfires burning across North Central Washington Wildfires are raging throughout the state, and a dry, windy forecast calls for worsening conditions across North Central Washington. Read more . (Bettina Hansen / The Seattle Times) “This was a tragic incident, and our hearts go out to their families, friends and colleagues,” said Mike Williams, the Forest Supervisor for the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest.
The Forest Service has called in a national Incident Management Team to investigate the deaths of the firefighters.
Zbyszewski was from the small town of Carlton, Okanogan County. His Facebook page indicates he was active in drama classes and had been a lifeguard at Wagner Memorial Pool in Twisp.
College President Kathy Murray sent an email Thursday notifying the “Whitman Community” of Zbyszewski’s death.
“I am deeply saddened to share the news that one of our students, Thomas Zbyszewski, was one of the three firefighters who died on Wednesday in the line of duty while serving on a five-person Forest Service engine crew battling the Twisp Fire in Okanogan County, near his hometown of Carlton, Washington,” Murray wrote.
Murray described Zbyszewski as a junior physics major who was “very involved in the Theatre Department.”
Most recently, Murray wrote, Zbyszewski portrayed the Mushroom King in the Instant Play Festival, Rusty in the “Junglers” (The One Act Play Contest) and the son in “Three Tall Women.”
He also had “a passion for the Chinese language and loved Whitman,” the email said.
David Dinsmore III, on his Facebook Quote: : “I worked with Tom Zbyszewski for two summers as a lifeguard in Twisp. Tom was one of a kind and I would find myself talking and laughing with him for hours on end. He was an incredibly intelligent young man and someone I looked up to.
“Rest in Peace my friend, you were loved by many more than you could’ve ever known.”
Zajac lived in Winthrop, in Okanogan County, and was a wildland firefighter with the Forest Service (USFS). Originally from Illinois, he received a degree in biology from Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland in 2010 and a master’s of science degree from the University of South Dakota in 2014, according to his LinkedIn page.
Zajac was a two-year starter at right tackle for Case Western’s football team, and was named an honorable mention to the all-university athletic association team during his senior year in 2009.
He had previously worked as firefighter in New Mexico.
Wheeler, a 10-year veteran seasonal firefighter in the Okanogan, was working on a career in public-land management, said his father-in-law, Doug Gruber. Wheeler had married Gruber’s daughter, Celeste, in 2013 and lived in South Haven, Mich., during the offseason. They did not have children, Gruber said.
Wheeler had just graduate from Grand Valley State College in Allendale with a degree in natural resources, Gruber said.
The Lyon family gathered at Harborview on Wednesday night and stood vigil by his bedside. The injured firefighter’s older brother believed Lyon “could register” that they were all there.
“Oh man, he’s a good kid all around. He’s definitely the favorite child,” said Levi Lyon, 35, of Tacoma
Richard Lyon has mostly third-degree burns on half to two-thirds of his body, according to Dr. Tam Pham, a University of Washington Medicine surgeon and burn-trauma specialist. He is undergoing the resuscitative phase, which involves replacing fluid. Depending on how things progress, he may move to the operative phase by Friday.
He will have a long road toward recovery, Pham said.
Lyon, a Rogers High School graduate and a reserve officer for the Milton Police Department, signed up to fight wildfires simply because he wanted to help, Levi Lyon said Thursday.
“His hope and dream was to be a police officer,” he said. “He was doing some forest firefighting to get some extra work. He was trying to help out a good cause.”
Richard Lyon is the youngest of three children. The siblings grew up in Puyallup. Their parents, a truck driver father and a schoolteacher mother, recently moved to Montana, where they had recently built their dream house.
This was Lyon’s first wildfire fighting season, his parents, Daniel and Barbara Lyon, said a news conference Thursday afternoon at Harborview.
He would call his parents every day and tell them not to worry, that things were going well.
“He talked about the exhilaration,” Daniel Lyon said. “When you’re young, you only talk about the good aspects.”
Washington State Patrol troopers and the Okanogan County Sheriff’s Office were at the scene of the fatalities, which involved an initial-attack crew in a truck Wednesday on state Department of Natural Resources (DNR) land near Twisp.
Okanogan County Sheriff Frank Rogers said Thursday that the dead and injured firefighters were part of the same crew. He confirmed that there had been a vehicle accident, but he said that it appeared at this point that the deaths and injuries were fire-related.
He declined to say whether any of the firefighters were able to deploy their emergency fire shelters.
Sheriff’s detectives were processing the scene and would oversee the removal of the remains later Thursday, the sheriff said. The USFS and local fire agencies would be responsible for determining how the deaths occurred.
Rogers said further details would be released by the Forest Service.
At a news conference Thursday morning, Gov. Jay Inslee said the wildfires have “burned a big hole in our state’s heart.”
In the meantime, the Forest Service had called in reinforcements to battle the Twisp fire, Forest Service spokeswoman Shoshona Pilip-Florea said.
Two Incident Management Teams — the highest level of wildfire-coordination teams — were en route to Twisp.
One of the teams will assist with fighting the complex of fires that has burned more than 30,000 acres, and the second will investigate the fire deaths.
The Forest Service also initiated its “critical response protocol” for the incident, which deploys a team to conduct an analysis of what led to the fatalities as a prevention learning tool, Pilip-Florea said.
The agency also coordinated crisis liaisons to assist families of the dead and injured firefighters, as well as Forest Service employees affected by the tragedy.
“We have a critical incident stress-management team coming in for support,” she said.
In Twisp, which remains under mandatory evacuation, Public Lands Commissioner Peter Goldmark described the fire as having “pretty explosive growth.”
Goldmark said winds are expected to be gusting again Thursday, to “make things extremely difficult” for firefighters.
Given the deaths of the firefighters, Goldmark said people shouldn’t undertake “heroic” acts just to save buildings.
“It’s a grim reminder of how dangerous it is” to fight such fires, he said Thursday.
This season, 13 people have died battling wildfires, including the three in Washington, said Jessica Gardetto of the National Interagency Fire Center in Boise, Idaho. She said it was a high number but could not immediately compare it to other years.
“Our firefighting personnel have been particularly hard hit this year,” said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, calling it an “extraordinarily challenging wildfire season.”
Seattle Times staff reporters Mike Carter, Paige Cornwell, Steve Miletich, Jennifer Sullivan, Lewis Kamb, Joseph O’Sullivan and Ángel González contributed to this story, which includes information from The Associated Press. Miyoko Wolf, news researcher, contributed to this report. Lewis Kamb: lkamb@seattletimes.com
